I have to say, the video was excellent on a purely technical information level. However, this video very neatly skirted the problem of abuse by authorities, systemic racism and the very real problem of this simply falling in the wrong hands by any means. All gatekeepers are fallible. The moral discussion was interesting, but mostly fruitless. The question is not simply one of privacy. The argument for safety in itself can be made both for and against these databases. The tone and structure of the video allowed the people you interviewed to frame it as a false dichotomy between privacy and safety. This false framing of social issues is a problem very prevalent in the mostly white male skeptic and scientific communities. I cannot claim to know the answer to these questions about genetic databases, but if poorly informed legislators and judiciaries are going to have the necessary sources of information to decide on this topic and impact the US and its spheres of political influence, our conversations as a general society require more incisive informational sources from our leading science communicators, and I believe you to be one of them. Good start, but doing the true problem in this video justice deserved more. I hope that future videos with such socially focused content will question core concepts as comfortably as your math and physics videos do. Keep up the good work.

You were given a deceptive, inaccurate slide at 5:26 . The "Probability of this STR Profile" number would be valid *If every one of those frequencies was randomly distributed with perfect independence, with zero correlation*. But they're not. In a real population, they're highly correlated. Which if you're doing the biostatistics correctly, instead of catering to cops & prosecutors who have little interest in the truth*, should make a false match many orders of magnitude more probable.

Picture 6 genes, each with a 10% population prevalence in a city. If they're perfectly uncorrelated, it's a 1 in a million chance that somebody has all 6 in the correct configuration to produce a match. But if they're perfectly correlated, if the Pacific Islander ethnic minority in the city (10%) has all the genes flipped in one direction, and the white population (90%) has all the genes flipped in the other direction? Then all Pacific Islanders will be matched to all other Pacific Islanders, and all white people will be matched to all other white people. The probability of two random people's samples matching each other is 82% (0.9*0.9 + 0.1*0.1). The degree of correlation produces an enormous difference, and you can NEVER assume perfectly uncorrelated genes.

The additional factor of family tree analysis only adds extra uncertainty.

This was never much of a concern with early DNA work, precisely because these huge databases didn't exist, so there wasn't much chance of a random false match ruining somebody's life. DNA was only gathered from suspects.

The future is full genome sequencing, or at least a hell of a lot more than 20 genes.

*See the fraudulent fields of hair analysis & arson investigation

I'm disappointed in this video, it was basically all copaganda. There was no coverage of the harm this technology and these techniques have done to misidentified suspects. Genetic fingerprinting is imperfect and cops are not statisticians/geneticists. Law enforcement has a long history of deploying poor or even nonsensical forensic techniques to manufacture evidence. As an example, the FBI used hair analysis to identify suspects for decades only to admit in 2015 that it's not actually a reliable forensic method. Even fingerprint matching suffers from a dearth of published scientific papers.

the right for privacy is in the constitution for good reason. I think it shouldn't be lawful to be able to be identified for whatever purpose, law enforcement or other, through relatives. I don't trust the authorities to not abuse that system in the future for other things like healthcare premiums, education eligibility and so on.

If you (they) could guarantee that the data is 100% only used for finding scum like murderers, sex offenders, child abductors or maybe people who wear crocs unironically AND guarantee that no innocent people will end up in jail just because a jury does not understand DNA tests and fingerprints are not foolproof, I have absolutely no problem with this. Same would go for automated cameras in public spaces or a few other potential "security features", that could make criminal acts never worth the risk.

Sadly this will be used for profiling, for marketing, for a whole bunch of stuff we cannot even dream of right now. This type of data will absolutely be used politically, it will be used by insurance companies, by financing institutes. Depending on how easy it is to draw conclusions or get someone to analyze it, it will be used to vet potential employees or tenants. You know it, I know it, they know it.

So unless this access would be so restricted, the data so protected and every single attempt to cheat the system so publicly and unequivocally punished, I cannot in good faith say I would welcome it.

I completely understand the data scientist saying, he needs as much data as he can get, to be able to make the best predictions or find murderers and rapists and kidnappers the fastest.
The thing that I'd argue is, it is the same as with other modern technologies like social networks. There was a cultural shift (ok maybe not as much for gen sequencing) which subconsciously moved lots of people to give up their privacy for some benefit.
The thing, I find critical about this is:
Who is able to use the data and what do they use it for. With Cambridge Analytica we saw a case of a massive amount of data being used to serve I'd say, a small minority at the cost of millions.
DNA on the other hand is even more complex as you mentioned, because you share it with your family. My worst fear is this being used in Helth insurance and the subsequent discrimination against people who had less favorable odds and maybe genommen engineering to circumvent this discrimination. On the other hand it is a great tool for law enforcement to solve crimes (but for that law enforcement needs to be actually enforce the law, which is something I'm doubting sometimes in the USA).
So in the end my conclusion is this:
DNA databases are one of the greatest tools in understanding our history, in helping solving crimes and having the ability to be able to tell someone who doesn't know his parents, who they are. But as with every mighty tool, it can be abused to the detriment of a lot of people. So I say, the data should lay with the people, with the people overseeing who is doing what with the database and most importantly with the people defending the data vigorously against any attempts to chip away at the protected status of this database and it being used to serve a minority institead of the majority of people.

This is a dangerous utopia (or dystopia, those are the same anyway) and the commentary section does have plenty of good examples and arguments for why it is a slippery slopes.

But to me the roots of this utopia and what makes it dangerous from the beginning is that (by definition) an utopia is a ideal completely disconnected from the reality. What is that reality ? Simply that human nature is what it is, and even if we can think we will “evolve” to a “better” version of ourself (history taught us what usually happens when people believing in that got the power…), we will ALWAYS have imperfections, and the first and foremost is that deep rooted in each of us, in everyone, is violence. And everyone knows it. Just look at you deep inside in the mirror and tell me it’s not true. Thankfully only very few act it. But think about the Milgram experiment…or countless of other examples.
Thinking that you can get rid of violent criminals and crimes because you are maximizing the chance of finding the crime offender is absolutely not true. So yes, in an consequentialist way you will arrest more efficiently criminal. Thumbs up for the justice system. But no, you will not get rid of criminality.
One could say that lowering the criminality is better than nothing. I am not sure it will even lower it. And even if it does, what is the limit ? It’s a rabbit hole.
And all the other concerns in the other comments are valid too: biological father does not equal father, what are we gonna do the day you get a dictator in power etc etc …
Many more ethics issues and philosophical points could be raised from this technology. I think all of it is still obviously very interesting, I am a researcher in immuno genetic myself. But don’t believe science is the new god. With such tools we should be even more cautious but we aren’t so far…again, human nature.
So I don’t have an answer. All I can say is that my intuition is telling me: be careful, the road to hell is paved with good intentions.

So you never asked your audience the headline of your video, "Would you share your DNA to catch a killer?" Instead, you told your audience, you ARE sharing your DNA, and you SHOULD feel good about it, even though finger-prints have previously been used to falsely convict people, and yes, DNA has also been used to falsely convict people of crimes they didn't commit.

For the record, no, I would not willingly share my DNA "to catch a killer", for the exact same reason I would not answer questions from Police "to catch a killer". First, it's not my responsibility to assist with their investigation. Second, they CAN use anything I say, or even my DNA, to erroneously cause me a ton of grief even if I am wholly innocent of the crime being investigated.

This should not be allowed. Even if you have a tissue sample, running DNA analysis is akin to a search. You need a warrant for that. And using family DNA to reconstruct someone else's DNA is also basically a search. You're searching millions of innocent people, people who did not agree to be searched, to find one criminal. If you're ever on a jury and this was the case, tell them not guilty.

In the case of the guy assaulting the old lady, the case should have been thrown out. The evidence was obtained illegally.

No one is making the claim that this applies anywhere besides their environment (geographically speaking), of course--but the item that sticks in my mind is the line saying something to the effect of "if you're a person in the US of European descent, you're in this data set" (from a part earlier on in the video). But race is pretty huge in this conversation. Regardless of what you think about racial "propensities to crime," this is a huge piece of the data that is missing. Imagine someone accuses a person who isn't white (going by broad strokes; eastern europeans are a significant population that gets slighted by what a lot of people see as a monolithic identity/experience of whiteness) of a crime and, because of their race, they cannot rightly be linked NOR exonerated of the crime...that is an objectively awful problem.
Of the three articles given as references (one of which is hosted on Elsevier which is...unfortunate (use scihub though, easy)), the first makes no mention of racial representation disparity; the second is about who supports these genetic processes in forensics, so mention of race is strictly about representation within the sample of people asked; the third mentions race in the context to say that race is extremely poorly balanced in the dataset and its therefore undermines its utility in certain ways.

This is incredibly troubling. Privacy is so misunderstood, people think : "I've done nothing wrong, this doesn't apply to me, they can use my information." But it's not about you, it never was. It's about those who have access to it, what they can do with it, and what they could become in the future. And it's that last point that's critical. There's no way to know if and when your own government can take a turn for the worse. It's happened countless times throughout history and it's happening right now in several countries like China, Russia, Belarus, Afghanistan, to name a few. With such a tool to their arsenal, a government can dictate what is right or wrong and have the means to have absolute control. "It doesn't apply to me" you say? Think again.

Safety is never a reason to actively violate rights. Proper safety is defensive in nature. It's why harsh lockdown policies are a no-go for me too, I mean just think of combining this level of tech with even the current level of government power to shut things down and quarantine people. Consider this one: Services like 23 and me are developing an ever growing database of genetics that are linked to individuals, who are then encouraged to add pictures to build out family trees. This is linking phenotypes (the physical characteristics) to the genotypes. Now consider the progression of machine learning and facial recognition in the past few years. In my opinion, we are getting very close to machine learning algorithms being able to train on this growing database of individuals genetics and faces to the point that they can be fed a dna sample and produce a face or even an entire body of somebody that’s previously unidentified. The implications of that type of technology would be interesting to say the least.

At the end of the day though, as long as a few protections were in place and it was exclusive to law enforcement, I couldn't care less if they plucked monsters like weeds using everyone's DNA. Clearly it's an interesting discussion. "Privacy" now, and for some time, has largely been an illusion (delusion?). DNA analysis certainly has the ability to definitely exclude a suspect from criminal investigation thus limiting police corruption, prosecutorial malfeasance, etc. How many have been falsely convicted based on highly unreliable "eye witness" testimony? Are fingerprints truly unique? Proof? Crime labs have been incompetent as well. I'm more interested in keeping innocent people out of prison than in catching a murderer (usually an isolated crime of passion). Obviously a serial killer or other repeated violent criminal is a major exception.

Privacy is such a strange thing these days.  We're so very concerned with maintaining privacy, but then carry around GPS trackers, allow web services to record our activities, willingly send our genetic code to companies, and publishing our daily lives on social platforms.  Odds are, your credit cards and personal identifying information are available for purchase from data miners, hackers, government agencies, and directly from companies we interact with.  At this point it seems most of us are safe from identity theft just due to the large number of other potential victims.  I think finding that balance between privacy and the power of data mining is one of the greatest tasks of the century.

My concern with the potential future of this technology will always be that it can be abused by those who don't understand it. A recent statics estimation found about 6% of Americans hold extreme alt-right ideologies analogous with those of modern Nazis. That is potentially MILLIONS of police, lawmakers, doctors, and private citizens who support racial superiority ideologies who could potentially gain access to and discriminate against people based on their genetic information. We have done this before in our history. Beginning in 1965, and based on what we now consider bad science, males with 47 chromosomes (XXY and XYY) were targeted as supposedly prone to more violent criminal behavior than men with 46 chromosomes (XY). While the majority of the scientific community abandoned this conclusion, a quick internet search found that as late as 2012 this hypothesis was still being making it's way into scientific papers. As we have seen with climate change legislation in the US, it doesn't take the majority of specialists to to convince lawmakers with preconceived assumptions that those assumptions are correct. Indeed they are just as likely to grab hold of any publication, no matter how flawed, to use as evidence that their assumptions are true. It therefore doesn't take a large leap to see a lawmaker with alt-right ideology using unsupported scientific claims to target racial and sexual minorities based on their DNA. This potential future is the one that most concerns me.

I am wary as hell of people who say things like "if you weigh public safety against the need for privacy, public safety is far more important."

They never want to acknowledge that governments and authorities are, by far, the worst offenders for exploiting and killing their own populations.

Each time we give up more privacy to the state, we are solidifying the tools of a theoretical (or current...) fascist police state.

In the US, we have lawmakers passing increasingly harsh and restrictive laws on protest and public demonstration, are cracking down on protest movements and protesters individually, and our failure to address these privacy issues and enshrine these rights in law, is making it easier and easier for state and local governments and law enforcement agencies to tighten the noose around dissidence.

It seems crazy to me, absolutely crazy, that in a time where huge chunks of US politics are slipping toward far-right doctrine and voter suppression to entrench far-right politicians - at a time with a nation-wide call to end police violence against minorities, that anyone would suggest that the government and law enforcement agencies can be trusted with an entire nation's chemical identifiers, just to solve a crime.

As an avid family historian - my DNA is already in all sorts of sites and one of them is GEDmatch. It didn't bother me if I was going to be checked when detectives are looking for vicious criminals. It never occurred to me how much my enthusiasm for genealogical DNA was illuminating everybody around me! Would it be extremely incongruous to say that I really hope I'm not related to any murderers or rapists? Obviously. Would it bother me if my DNA was used to find a brutal criminal that I'm related to? No. No - I think I can live with that.

They didn't talk about triangulation! They could have cut the corner on that whole family tree work if they'd done a bit of triangulation, first. People should NOT be using these services. It's very important, personal data that you have no control over where it's going. The potential for abuse is enormous.
Maybe the company you use has really good privacy rules. But as this video shows, companies can be bought out, and policies changed.
But your DNA doesn't change. This woman uses Duck duck go to reduce companies knowing things like her browsing/search history, her likes and dislikes, IP address etc.
These are all things which can and do change over time. So the privacy loss in a sense, isn't permanent. It's also only your data you're giving up.
A DNA test is PERMANENT. It's who you are, and it never changes. Your phone number or address gets leaked - it's bad, but you can change it. Not your DNA.

Also, the 'helping identify relatives' thing, while great for law enforcement, can also be abused. Maybe no-one will use it against you. But what about your relatives?

There was an incident that cropped up maybe 5 years ago in the US and I wonder if anyone else remembers the story, if the theory of what happened was correct and knows, if it was correct, how it affected our understanding of DNA

The story was a couple were having DNA tests done on themselves for something to do with their kid. I can’t for the life of me remember why, but I assume it was to do with an
Illness. Following the completion of the tests, it turned out the father’s DNA didn’t match. The assumption by the testers was that the wife had had an affair, which both parents vehemently denied (I found it admirable that the husband/father refused to accept the results rather than losing his mind). Despite the clinic stating there was virtually a zero percent chance of cross-contamination, the test was carried out again. Same result.
Once again, the couple denied the result, both absolutely steadfast in their beliefs and, if memory serves, one more test was carried out with the same result.
The couple still refused to accept the result and it took one of the specialists at the clinic to try a new approach so, instead of taking a DNA sample from the cheek as they had been he took a sample of DNA from his sperm and this time there was a match.

After much speculation and pondering, the theory that gathered most traction was that, during conception, two sperm fertilised the egg at exactly the same time causing some kind of split in his DNA. This always seemed completely implausible to me, but I’m obviously no scientist. If the theory is true, it opens the door to a lot of questions regarding parentage, crime, etc.

So I knew about all this thanks to a really really good podcast I listened to recently. So I am kind of biased against this video because as it gives more insight into the companies who do the DNA testing and how it works it is kind of one sided and repetitive in its pro and con genetic database arguments.
Also the title is blatantly untrue. Your relatives DNA is in a Database, your own DNA is not. This is important as you only get matched through the database if law enforcement (or somebody else) takes a DNA sample of you personally against your consent. And I really do hope that only happens in case of a committed crime.
This video is also very USA centered. Ancestral research via these databases is very popular in the US compared to the rest of the world. I personally think that's because they have a generally higher chance to find some exciting off continent relatives than the typical central European whose ancestors lived there for the past 1000 years.
Another thing that isn't mentioned here is that this method of finding criminals heavily relies on being able to find relations to a common ancestor who lived potentially several hundred years ago. Again the US makes this relatively easy as that data about relation has been largely digitalized. In other counties one would have to drive from town to town to look up family relations in old church papers and town records. Consequently while this truly is as much of a breakthrough as the fingerprint identification the process is not as smooth and foolproof as it seems here. There are also several other morally problematic parts about this which weren't discussed at all.
That being said this video had a certain scientific naivety to it which I normally love about the channel. The pure excitement of the people involved would have usually made me more excited. As this was not new to me I was long over the excitement and was only thinking of how serious of a topic this is without being able to enjoy watching.

It is totally different to have DNA taken from a crime scene, find a suspect and match the DNA .... or .... To have a DNA sample point to a suspect and then check that suspect out!
Just like there are more than one person with fingerprints that match one sample so too are there more than one person with the DNA to match a sample. The odds are vanishingly small with prints (average two people with the same prints in the UK 70 Million population) and several orders of magnitude smaller for DNA! ..... But it is still there. And the way it is used matters. Also the way it is used is lost on most people!


As I understand it the process of getting the DNA profile involves cutting the DNA up, replicating the parts and then sequencing them. Because of this multiplication of the bits contamination is a real issue. When you think about it it is unlikely a swab sample can be viewed as pure. how many surfaces are untouched except by one person after a sterile clean? There may well be several different DNA strands collected in one sample, cut up, replicated and then sequenced! It is the computer algorithm that adds the bits together to form a whole.

I say this not to prevent the use of DNA but to have it used safely and reliably!

One thing really not talked about here is what happens to this data if these companies go out of business. A VC or investment group comes in and buys them and decides you know they don't really care as much about privacy. It's nice to put a face on it assuring that this data will never be used in ways people don't want, but this data is forever and only as good as long as those people still have their jobs and/or spines. The health insurance angle is one good push back on these, but I don't think that is anywhere near the worst use case. What if this becomes available for companies hiring people? Or governments using them not to find criminals but identify racial and/or family groups in very precise ways for oppression or extermination? Or widening the definition of "crimes" that are applicable for these searches by force of law. There's an incredible amount of misplaced trust in a massive permanent genetic database ONLY being used for specific purposes forever from the people appearing in this video. Imagine if this data was available in Rwanda in the 90's, or the Khmer Rouge. In a sense these databases would be among the top priorities of authoritarian governments and revolutionaries to get their hands on, it's makes the targeting of racial and ethnic groups in hiding trivial and precise. All it takes is a security breach as well for these carefully crafted terms of service and promises to be rendered meaningless.

I think this is a necessary step to forming a safer society. There's already been a dramatic decline in serial killings, no doubt partially because of this, and a more expansive database could lead to all sorts of other types of murders seeing a similarly dramatic decline (murder has been declining dramatically, but you know what I mean). Obviously we can never eradicate all crime, but a non-intrusive way to try needs to be tried.
Emphasis on non-intrusive.
Before this can really be trusted, we need SERIOUS reforms to our law enforcement system. We can't trust a law enforcement system with all of our DNA if there aren't well informed experts making the decisions, which there just aren't right now, and we DEFINITELY can't trust them if their decisions have literally ZERO oversight. We need to be able to trust that if a law enforcement agency makes a mistake, or purposefully misrepresents the data, there's another agency who'll clean up the mess and set things right.
Internal investigations need to become EXTINCT before we can trust these sorts of things. Investigations into law enforcement conduct should always be done by a neutral third party.

DNA evidence can as easily be exculpatory as incriminating. With all respect to all the honest cops and prosecutors out there I have to wonder if the police and prosecutors in possession of other circumstantial evidence linking a person to a given crime would be as enthusiastic in revealing exculpatory DNA evidence as they would incriminating DNA evidence. If they can make a strong case against an accused without the pesky exculpatory DNA evidence which would exonerate them would they be as quick to pursue that case as they would when there is, say, 2nd or 3rd cousin DNA evidence linking the accused to said crime. It is said to be impossible to prove a negative but it would appear that DNA evidence would be able to prove that a given individual did not - AND COULD NOT - commit a given criminal act. What is to stop police and prosecutors from ignoring such evidence? THAT is what worries me. 200 years ago in South America, there was an entire social hierarchy based around racial heredity called Las Castas which was enforced by law.  After that, phrenology was all the craze.  100 years ago, eugenics swept through academia and the intelligencia (if you're watching this, 100 years ago you probably would have been fully on board with eugenics) and that lead directly to that guy from Austria who was REALLY interested in genetic histories.  The current cultural zeitgeist is not to do away with racial hierarchies, but to flip them.  We can already think of some very good reasons to not allow governments and law enforcement access to our genetic data, but those aren't the most compelling reasons.  The most compelling reasons are the ones to which we response, "yeah, well, that could never happen here or now."  Yes they can.  Yes they will.

Problem with me is side effects it can have.  Security is crappy in many organizations and companies.  So all of that centralized information could be leaked.  Or health insurance companies could eventually raise rates.  Or could deny coverage because that condition was already a preexisting condition before you got the health insurance.

There's a core assumption here that isn't being sufficiently questioned - that the existence of your DNA at a crime scene is sufficient evidence that you were there and did the crime. For a serial criminal, finding the same DNA at the location of every crime is probably pretty reliable (although there must surely by now be some criminals who carry around a vial of someone else's DNA to leave at scenes). But for a single event, there are all sorts of reasons why it should not be considered sufficient evidence to convict on its own - even before we get into things like contamination and laboratory scandals. DNA evidence is routinely presented in court as being infallible, when for many reasons it may not be.

This was indeed a very well done video with some wonderful graphics but unfortunately, the video has many factual errors.
- Brett Williams of Verogen stated that there is just a single marker responsible for blue eyes. In fact we now know that there are multiple markers involved in the genetics of eye colour.
- The video incorrectly stated that familial searching can be done in the CODIS database. Strictly speaking CODIS is the name of the software used for performing searches in the criminal databases in the US (the same software is also used in some other countries). There are in fact three different criminal databases in the US: local DNA databases, state DNA databases and a federal database known as the National DNA Index System (NDIS). CODIS is often used as a synonym for CODIS. The FBI have specifically prohibited familial searching in NDIS. Many thousands of crimes could potentially be solved if this were allowed. And of course many more cases could be solved if all the backlogs were cleared and all the lawfully owed DNA were collected.
- The reporter incorrectly suggested that GEDmatch was used to solve the Golden State Killer case. As the LA Times revealed, it was in fact the MyHeritage database which provided the crucial lead, though both GEDmatch and FTDNA were also used.
- The video mentioned the Utah case which resulted in the change in the terms and conditions at GEDmatch whereby the entire database was opted out of law enforcement matching and everyone had to pro-actively opt in. They failed to mention the change of policy in January 2021 whereby the entire database was opted in for matching with unidentified human remains. This change was not transparent and the terms and conditions are currently highly ambiguous. And of course it is some of the unidentified human remains cases which are of the most concern (eg, the potential use of genetic genealogy to identify fetal remains, Baby Doe cases, etc).
- The reporter talked about conflicting views to sharing with law enforcement and presented this entirely as an issue relating to privacy. There has been quite a lot of research on this subject and there are in fact many different issues, eg, lack of informed consent, lack of regulation and oversight, the trans-national nature of the databases, the punishments for the crimes in the US which can result in someone’s DNA being used to identify someone who receives the death penalty, etc.

We covered all these issues in a review article in Forensic Science International Genetics "Investigative genetic genealogy: current methods, knowledge and practice" published earlier this year which the video's creators somehow seem to have missed.

I'm one of the people who wants to err on the side of privacy.

On the other hand, I have to point out that crimes are rarely solved with the consent of the perpetrator. There are many types of evidence, and witnesses are one of those. Being able to identify one person through other people's DNA is not that different from people testifying in court against somebody else.

But my concern isn't really crime. It's abuse in a multitude of ways that are too early to even predict at this point. Just as corporations are abusing our personal data constantly right now, I'm certain that corporations will find ways to either extrort money directly from us based on DNA or will sell our DNA profiles with other companies that will. The problem is that we no longer have a choice, and as someone pointed out in the video, it's not something we can change like getting a new credit card or an ID card from a different authority. One area that should be of special concern is Witness Protection programs. What difference does building a new identity for someone as a permanent cover make when their DNA can't be changed? Even if they never have contact with anyone they know or to whome they are related, their DNA can be obtained without their knowledge (I mean their actual DNA, not a relative's) and inadvertently be used to identify them. With DNA databases cropping up all over the place, an individual with nefarious ulterior motives could search those databases under false pretenses. And the databases could be hacked or leaked.

This is a slippery slope that scares the crap out of me.

Nazi Germany is about 80 years old today. That's not even a single human lifespan. And 30 years before, a regime like that was completely unthinkable. What happens 80 years from now? I feel, especially after the whole point about clickbaiting you've made before, that this title is very misleading. What you state is 'Your DNA is in a database' but in the video it becomes 'Your possibly very distant relative's DNA might be in a database if they have voluntarily provided DNA to an DNA analysis service'. That second one is not a catchy title because it is not really an interesting fact. Obviously if people give up their DNA for analysis, the DNA will be in the hands of the people doing the analysis. The conclusions drawn from that (that a lot of people may be identifyable by DNA without ever giving up their own DNA) is not as applicable to viewers as you present either because it is very US-centric. These DNA services are not as widespread outside of the US as they are within it. The claim that 'Your DNA is in a database' is likely false for many viewers, even with the most stretched interpretation of that title. I know I sound pedantic pointing this out, but I feel a channel like yours should be above the practice of embelishing the truth for views. The truth itself should be interesting enough without misrepresenting it. Don't underestimate your potential viewers by lowering yourself to clickbait. Keep making good content and people will keep clicking.

The discussion is much bigger than protecting one's privacy vs helping law enforcement.

It's about other people making decissions that impact you and where there's no option to opt-out.
It's about the risk of a slipperly slope (now it's homicide and sexual abuse, soon it'll be for a stupid bar fight).
It's about trusting law enforcement and government installing proper controls on the use of this data and obeying it.
It's about trusting LE and government not using this data for anything other than solving crimes (e.g. not searching for some sort of "gay DNA marker" in very conservative countries).
It's about trusting that whatever regulations and controls which would be implemented in this day and age remain valid forever in the future, throughout multiple governments and probably a few more worldwide crisises.
It's about trusting that this data is only uses by LE to search for offendors. I can imagine private companies wanting this data to tailor advertising based on how food tastes for you or your hair type, but also insurance companies denying insurance (or asking astronomical prices) for people who are likely to get some sort of chronic disease.

That faux set of scales at 24:27 that the cold case investigator made really pissed me off. He made two massive errors there. First off, he assumed not only that everyone agrees with the idea of greater and lesser rights, but also that they rank them the same. But secondly, and perhaps even more egregiously, he weighed up the individual rights of a crime victim against the individual privacy rights of other individuals who may be against such technologies being used like this, when in fact the more accurate comparison would one heinous crime victims rights versus the privacy concerns (which we'll assume are of lesser importance) of millions of other people. Or, to be perfectly accurate, the quest for justice of a few thousand crime victims versus million or possibly even billions of other peoples' privacy concerns. EVEN IF we treat privacy as a 'lesser issue', it STILL gets magnified massively by the sheer number of people it affects, versus just a few thousand victims. The scales aren't level at all.

That said, the scariest part of the video is when the Verogen CEO at 23:04 shared the percentage of new users who seem to be okay with signing away their privacy, as that points to a cultural shift towards just accepting that privacy is increasingly being seen as an outmoded concept. I'm willing to be a large percentage of those users who said 'Yes' were also young, have grown up with internet tracking and so have just come to accept it. Reminds me of a Tom Scott video from a awhile ago titled 'Privacy is Dead', in which he acts as a hypothetical person from the future describing the 'Brave New World' in which, well, privacy is dead. And in fact it also reminds me of the Aldous Huxley novel 'Brave New World', which on the surface is presented as utopic even though it's really meant as a dystopian future society. People keep wringing their hands bringing up Orwells' 1984-style surveillance societies, but what they're really sleeping on is a 'Brave New World'-style future, which nowadays is looking far closer to reality than Orwells' opus. And that statistic at 23:04 is another real world instance pointing in that direction.

It isn't misuse - if you have a proclivity to Parkinsons, say - and obviously that can be determined by a DNA test - then that is "Required Disclosure".
IF you don't disclose that fact then you are trying to rip-off all the other people.
Here, try this, I am pretty-much going to die because of Diabetes complications, but I don't disclose that and I claim insurance for a toe that had to be amputated, "yeah, nah, that was totally coz of a lawnmower accident" - then everyone else's insurance goes UP because of my failure to disclose.
Yeah, it was a bad example and I don't have Diabetes, but the point stands that insurance is based on what can be known - if you want to hide things from yourself and from the insurance company then you're trying to fool yourself and trying to take from the common-good.

That guy who said that on one hand you have someone's privacy and on the other hand you have someone who's daughter was murdered, the scale is way on the side of the woman who's daughter was murdered is making a false equivalency.

On the one hand you have someone's right to privacy, which is a constitutional right in America. It's something so fundamental it was enshrined in our bill of rights in the 4th amendment.

On the other hand you have someone who wants justice for a crime.

There is no justification for violating someone else's rights to achieve justice for a crime.

If you were allowed to violate someone's rights to achieve justice, then torture would be perfectly legal and morally acceptable. You could strap someone to a chair, starve them, beat them, and question them until you get the information you want, but of course we all know that's not acceptable.

While I am making an extreme comparison to prove the point, the point still stands. If you can't deny someone their right to freedom to make an arrest, how can you deny them their right to privacy?

And we all know this won't stop at identifying people who've committed actual crimes. We all know the government will use it to find and abuse people who have committed no crime, but who are enemies of those in power. This is the most dystopian thing I've ever heard about, much worse than the NSA databases or Chinese social scoring system. This technology makes it trivially easy for someone to be framed or for government to crack down on dissenters or other "undesirables".
Imagine if the former East German (DDR) government had had this. They could have gone to the home of a single person known to be "anti-revolutionary", collect DNA samples and find everyone who visited that flat in the past.
Imagine the police in Hong Kong waiting till a protest ended, collecting used bottles & cans, fallen hair strands, etc. and mass arresting everyone who has taken part after the fact, when they don't have strength in numbers.
Worst of all, the mere existence of this technology makes it easy for law enforcement to just claim that they've found your DNA at the scene of some crime and connect it to you. They can just lie and say that they found you through the process described in this video. They couldn't do so before because they would have had to have follow due process to get the individuals' DNA in the first place in order to connect the DNA at the scene of the crime with the individual, making that far easier to challenge in court. Now they can just get your DNA through covert/illegal means, claim they collected it at the scene of the crime and then, through this database, get to you as the suspect.
That's trivially easy to do for a single dirty cop.

I noticed that the medical aspect for DNA testing wasnt really addressed in this video, outside of the brief mention regarding health insurance. I recently made the decision to have DNA testing specifically to find out if I inherited the PKD (polycystic kidney disease) gene from my dad, since he is only 52 yet is on dialysis, and has comorbidities such as extremely high blood pressure & 4 heart attacks due to his PKD. In an effort to mitigate that happening to me I would need definitive proof that I will develop PKD, thus the genetic testing. I will get my result in about a month.
I was informed prior to the consent form that my country currently has health insurance opting (not mandated) to not acquire the genetic results from people, but that this may in future change. I understand that the people who are private and not wish for their genetic profile to be made available due to 3rd cousins and such do not have a choice in this, but for those who seek testing for health related issues, there really isn't an argument to be made regarding the privacy of a 3rd cousin. It is unfortunate, but it holds true in that there is a balance, and of course no accounting for things outside their control.

This was super fascinating to see, I'm glad that the data for now (and hopefully for the future too) is only used in criminal/assault case because that's only a good thing. This is a great video on an extremely relevant topic. I think the trust in these kinds of tech/systems ultimately comes down to whether or not we trust our government (I'll speak strictly for the US here) to do the right thing, and how much we value our individual life over that of potentially greater societal benefit. That sounds obvious, but consider some examples. For those with concerns, do we (citizens of the US) believe, for example, that insurance companies would ever be allowed to sky rocket their rates for people born with specific (potential) genetic conditions (Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, etc.)? Or do we think the government would ultimately step in to balance this? The only real downside I can see to this kind of tech is accidently becoming accused of a crime you didn't commit. I do consider that a very serious tradeoff, but if that was the biggest hurdle, wouldn't companies/the government step in to address this? For any issue that arises, I truly believe society would ultimately swing in favor of a balance that allows for use of the DNA but which safeguards major concerns. Unless the government takes a turn towards history and becomes extremely corrupt (you know what I mean), I can't see the US moving in a less transparent/less protected direction. In fact, you see so much more transparency these days, and companies even saying, "Look, here is what we do, here is how we use your information. You can opt out, you can chose to not use the product, etc." And in the end, what's the worse that could happen anyway? Do the benefits of society outweigh your individual rights for your very short life? I am for this technology, but I also highly value individual rights. Ultimately, I think society will do the right thing, will try to find a healthy balance: otherwise, in maybe a third world country with a far more corrupt government, I would not want this tech.

Any system can be abused -- DNA is vastly more reliable and powerful for law enforcement, but it can equally be exploited by those with access, to frame innocent people. Secondly, there is a risk that this data can be weaponised in the future, where a foreign power owns/had access to this data they can exploit it to create bioweapons that target individual ethnic groups. Regulations need to be put in place to ensure the integrity of the system, not just of law enforcement but the corporate controls - would you trust Facebook with your DNA, who will sell access for fractions of a cent to insurance companies or Russian/Chinese researchers ?

This really starts making the movie 'The Minority Report' much more plausible.

Once this data is put into a database it is almost impossible to keep it secret indefinitely. If the company doesn't breach the terms of service (like Cambridge Analytica) or yield to a court order, even if the company is not bought out by a bad actor or seized by a malevolent or oppressive state, even if no laws pass to sweep aside privacy rights, even then there are hackers, and employees who will take bribes.

So you not only have to worry about genetic data ending up in the hands of law enforcement or an oppressive state. You also have to worry about it ending up in the hands of criminals, fanatics, terrorists, and hostile foreign powers.

To me, it's the same logic as wanting a back door to encryption for law enforcement to use in special circumstances. It sounds like a great idea. It will help countless people, right?
But, as Tom Scott said, "Nothing to hide only works if the folks in power share the values of you, and everyone you know, *entirely*, and always will"

Also from Tom Scott (in regards to backdoors for encryption, and somewhat applies here):
"It fails the bitter ex test. Can someone, with an agenda, use this to ruin a life?"

Perhaps these sites can't be used by someone with an agenda *right now*, but if the government and people in power change, and the laws change to say health insurance companies, potential employers, dating partners, extended family, etc. can look at your genetics/ancestry/heritage and use it discriminately against you, then privacy is completely gone, and you didn't even consent to it.

It would make more sense to apply these resources towards preventing crimes rather than prosecuting after they occur.

DNA is a phenominal tool and can be used to understand many things in the world and create unique and custom medicines. I will stand by the fact that personalized medicine will help treat the world much more effectivenly, alongside genetic recombination technologies. The technology is powerful but if data gets in the hands of non-scientists such as financial specialists, insurance companies, politicians, laywers, or law enforcement that's when we have societal destruction and introduce government or corporate control of ourseleves. Genetic data is great and useful, but so many people want to exploit it. We must protect it from the greedy.

It wasn't until I got older that I realized that DNA is the ultimate privacy. I have no problem with the police maintaining a database of DNA found at crime scenes. A database of DNA of people to use to identify crimes, however is intrusive. What probable cause could possibly justify law enforcement having my DNA profile if I am not a suspect in a particular crime? The government can't just (legally) tap my phone unless they can prove to a judge that I have already committed a crime. The government can't ransack my home for evidence of a crime unless I already gave them reason to believe I committed a crime. Government can't just put my life under a microscope without evidence I have broken a law. Even under the evidence of a crime, that still doesn't mean a warrant gives carte blanche over my life. The government can't force a spouse to give evidence against me either.

We defend the right from intrusion by government all the time. They can't just have a database of citizens who have knives or guns, despite the fact that those items are used in crimes occasionally. Why do we allow government to keep a database of people that near perfectly identifies them, despite never committing a crime?

Then after the DNA is taken and added to the database, that person will never be free again. They will never be anonymous. The government will ALWAYS view you as a suspect and your right against unlawful search has been forfeited forever.

Any time the government ever searches that database, they are searching YOU.

Then there's the ethical dilemma of health/life insurance companies, and the fact that they can look up family even if they don't have your profile, then use that to screw you.

No database of DNA should exist. Period.

There are legit reasons for people not wanting to be found that have nothing to do with being a criminal. Example: There are women who have been stalked and have to change their identity, or people hiding from organized crime. Being able to steal DNA and then using one of these services to find living relatives can be a really dangerous situation.

In the lord of the rings it was allegorically akin to the ring. Which was concluded to be needing of destruction.

Since we are likely not going to do that, and we must assume there are evils yet to be revealed that would use this power oppressively, the rules regarding the use of DNA should be so strict that you better be solving a capital crime or one with capital implications.

We've done pretty good as a species for only being able to catch X% of criminals. Increasing X by means of exposing ourselves to oppression will only decrease how we've done.

I understand the concern about insurance companies penalizing people because of genetic predispositions.  But I am not overly concerned about that.  First, because I am fairly certain that using genetic data like that will be outlawed shortly after (if not before) it would be practical for an insurance company to use it.  But second, because while having my second cousin's DNA might allow a DNA sample to be linked to me eventually, I doubt my cousins DNA will tell my insurance company all that much about my health.  Now there are conditions that run in families so it's not impossible for the data to be misused.  But if raising insurance premiums (or refusing to cover) based on a person's DNA profile would anger the public, doing so based on a person's second cousin's DNA profile would INFURIATE the public.  I just don't see it happening.  Also, I am not close with any of my second cousins so if my DNA profile helps prove one of them is a serial killer, I have no problem with it.  Honestly, if one of my siblings was a serial killer, I would still want them caught.

I'd never consent, but as shown here, it doesn't really matter. It's not a matter of being able to be proven innocent or "not having anything to hide." It's a matter of: What do you do if you know with 100% certainty that you did not kill or rape somebody but the prosecution is showing as evidence your DNA from one of these sources? You have no recourse, there's nothing you can do - you will go to jail and potentially be executed for something you didn't do. These entire systems rely on people being 100% honest and transparent every step of the way but they're not always 100% honest and transparent. The system is only as honest as the least honest person involved, yet this could be innocent peoples' lives.

EDIT:
This will eventually become a huge issue. And it sucks that this technology can be used to help catch murderers and rapists, but it can also be used to destroy peoples' lives, and at some point it WILL be used to destroy an innocent person's life, and at that point a couple people will be fired, and they'll be released from jail 20 years later, but that person's life still got screwed over because of this.

The right to privacy obviously cannot extend to genetics; you may decide not to upload your information, but you have no say in what a sibling, parent, or adult child chooses to do with theirs. Genetics are just one piece of solving the "unidentified person" puzzle: public and health records supply the other part of finding who a criminal might be, and yet there isn't some huge push to do away with record-keeping.

No, the big worry is, as was mentioned in the video, discrimination. Genetic information needs to be a protected class under the various laws prohibiting discrimination, and it should be codified into law that insurance companies, can have absolutely nothing to do with receiving, storing, or sharing any genetic data or any analyses done on that data.

I also believe that hospitals that work with genetic data must keep any data and analysis anonymized and/or encrypted with only the doctor and patient having the key. Neither doctor nor patient can be legally, medically, or otherwise compelled to share their key and doctors must destroy their patient's key when that patient is no longer in their care.

Smart homes are great! They make life easier. But they do so while tracking every bit of your life. Which should terrify anyone, at least a little bit.

I can see where using genetic information to help catch criminals can be a huge benefit to society in general.  Where I have a problem with using genetic modeling is in the corporate sector.  Life insurance companies are already trying in some places to use genetic information to determine eligibility and premiums.  I would hate to be placed on the high risk side of an actuary table just because my genetic information says that I might have an increased risk of kidney or heart issues, regardless of whether or not I actually HAVE those issues.  Thank goodness that HEALTH insurance companies, in the US at least, are barred from using genetic info to set rates or deny enrollment thanks to GINA, the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008.  But what about totally unregulated industries?  As genetic info becomes more ubiquitous and widespread, how long will it be before marketers use genetic information to start targeting people with specific markers?  You have a gene for pattern baldness?  We have a solution we will try to shove down your throat.  Personally, I think that the corporate world already knows too much about me, and some day my genetic information will just be one more tool used to manipulate me.

The “there will always be winners and losers” comment near the end of the video makes me think of Jamal Greene’s “How Rights Went Wrong.”

In it, he suggests that where our justice system has gone wrong is in the belief in absolute rights: one party’s rights in a particular case supersede those of the other party.

Instead, he proposes that society might benefit from acknowledgement of multiple rights, all valid, and a justice system that encourages mediation among those rights and the policies that are served by evaluation of the details of particular cases.

Not to get way too sci-fi on you all, but I want to represent a more extreme part of this debate. We've seen how much things can change in a hundred years as far as innovative technologies and social preferences, now imagine how utterly different things can be in another hundred years. You may think "I'll be dead, so it won't affect me" but if we let companies and institutions preserve intimate data like this without our input, a computer simulation of our consciousness is totally possible. Why would anyone want to do this? That's what we think about war, torture, sexual assault and terrorism; If something evil can be done there's a good chance it will be. With the rise of "data" driven companies like Google and Facebook, now is definitely the time to put our foot down as a populace to prevent the abuse of this technology. The good of catching criminals with the data should still be integrated but the data as a whole should be strictly private and secret, and the individual should be the one to make any and all decisions related to it's usage or access.

I guess I don't think that DNA is a big deal. Maybe living in a place with universal healthcare changes the equation - but what are people going to use my DNA for, really? As far as personal information goes, it's peanuts. Every social media profile carries far larger, tangible attack vectors to your self-interest.

The existence of your social media profiles is far, far worse. And I think that these sort of "doomsday" scenarios are so implausible that their weight in the equation is negligible. Realistically, the amount of good we could do if everyone's DNA was catalogued from a medical research and treatment perspective already makes it worth it in my mind, nevermind the identification aspects for law enforcement.

My biggest issue with this is the capacity for tyranny. They may only use the data for the worst of crimes now, but we have no way of knowing whether that will be a constant.
At what level of crime do we decide that this is too much, and how do we keep this threshold from being crossed?
If a law is unjust or tyrannical, the people have a duty to break it. But if this tech is applied to these cases, the people have no way of getting away with defying unjust laws.
Think about attending an illegal protest somewhere like China, if you leave even a bit of DNA on anything at the site of the protest, they could use that to convict you.

The argument here is strange, because there's a lot of arguing about public safety, but is it actually significant? All DNA testing can do is identify a person after a crime has already been committed, it could stop a crime from escalating further and it may deter a person from ever committing a crime, if they are intelligent enough in the first place to realise they could be identified. But personally I think the significance of those effects are probably pretty minor, and are really only side stepping the original issue of the crimes happening in the first place, and I think it's a pretty weak argument vs. the privacy concern, because there are still a lot of unknowns about how this data could be used negatively in the future. You can see the discomfort in the face of the guy who had to admit that yes, we don't know the future ramifications of access to this data, but with anything you can be sure someone, without your best interests in mind, will come up with something.
The percentage of people willing to sacrifice liberty for security is growing and growing.

I have never met a person who is pro-privacy on this topic that is against the idea of justice for murder victims. It always comes down to other issues, including that some of these companies (GEDMatch included) violate their ToS with users to share data with outside entities, and often the companies have the right to make those determinations without your consent or change the line.

Shrugging this off as NBD because if any one of 1,000 people share their data, it's "as good as you doing it," is largely irrelevant to the core concern most on that pro-privacy side have: A desire to have assurances against abuse in place first and a right to choose how their biological markers are used or not.

And as the Verogen rep stated, I think it IS OK that people on the pro-privacy side can't dictate to others... That's core to the idea of personal freedom, but I feel like this video is almost belittling the idea that the conversation matters.

comment_text: I feel like this subject is complicated, because supporting bringing criminals to justice is an undeniably good thing, but I do not trust the system to be used for that. The criminal justice system in this country is frankly horrifying in many aspects, and I do not believe it is a matter of if it is abused, but rather a question of how soon it will be abused. At which point, we have to wonder how do we create a system which can curb the abuses enough to keep the moral scales balanced at the very least. It might be a moot point, there may be no political will to curb abuses, at which point we just have to make our peace with it. At this point, the amount of good done with it is far outweighed by the bad, but I predict that will rapidly balance back out. And when it does, we will need to have a discussion on how to control a technology which is already out of control.

I think one part of the ethics discussion missed by this video is just how long lasting the effects are. Just because Ancestory, and 23andMe don't share their information now, doesn't mean they won't in the future. In addition, their sharing policies do nothing to stop a change in government from just forcing them to hand over the data at some point. A perfect example is the system the US used to certify people in Afghanistan as being safe to work with. Sure you could argue that it had a noble goal, and saved American lives or whatever. But since the withdrawal, the Taliban now has control of that system. The people registered in it are outed as US collaborators, and it's not like they can change their iris or fingerprint scans. Just because it's secure today, doesn't mean it'll be secure tomorrow. We're seeing a lot of ethno-nationalist activity across the world. Can you imagine what would happen if someone with those beliefs came to power in a country where this data was stored?..

Very interesting video covering this topic. I work as the Lead Forensic Genealogist at DNA Labs International, spending every day working on these types of cold cases (as an example, I was the genealogist for the Beth Doe/Evelyn Colon case). One interesting part of the conversation - which always seems to be left out, in my opinion - is exactly what is seen when doing these searches? "What does Law Enforcement have access to and what can they do with it?" It is a question I hear a lot and one that I think is utterly important in understanding this subject as a whole. Are there reasonable and realistic privacy concerns for the future with these types of DNA databases? Definitely. But if anyone honestly wanted your DNA, it would be much easier to just follow you around until you discard something, then they can extract a DNA sample from that item. The information seen by Law Enforcement in these databases for a forensic sample is the same access anyone would have if they tested at Family Tree DNA and then uploaded to gedmatch. There is no special access for Law Enforcement beyond exactly what anyone else would see from their own DNA test. In fact, the only difference is law enforcement has less access because they can't compare their DNA profile to anyone who has opted-out.

Those who trade their freedom for safety deserve neither. What's to stop law enforcement from abusing the data to catch whistle-blowers, journalists, activists, or even low level relatively harmless crimes such as drug possession? Even if they aren't abusing it now, one bad president or 9/11 like event could open the floodgates to rampant abuse of power.

The only thing that worries me about this was around 17:59 when they were showing off the DNA storage. Why do they have it? What is the point of storing the DNA if you already have the ~700,000 snips on that card or read into the computer? This kind of goes back to the point about health insurance companies using the data to charge more for someone who shows something in their DNA. So maybe they want to make sure they still have the DNA just in case that kind of thing happens but it isn’t found in the data they already pulled from it. Even if I believed in everything they are doing RIGHT NOW, I wouldn’t want my DNA sitting in cold storage waiting for the next CEO’s big idea to make money selling your info to________for_____.

Thank you for this information. - I'm disappointed there was little discussion about the investigation that I believe (and may be required by law) must be used to incriminate the innocent until proven guilty suspect independent of the DNA evidence. DNA evidence is great but it's not perfect.

For example, the DNA evidence generally only indicates that the suspect was at the seen of a crime or may even be involved in the crime but not the perpetrator. I sure hope the DNA I leave when I visit people I work with ends up being labeled as the magic evidence that links me to a felony. I wish protection of the innocent was actually discussed.

DNA evidence is also limited when we consider that many crimes like murder and sexual assault are perpetrated by people who are associated with the victim. That means the likelihood of DNA being a slam dunk is low. The case used in this video is an outlier.

We found DNA at the scene and now it's been matched to a suspect. Okay, now let's use this "lead" to find independent evidence that proves beyond a reasonable doubt, that this suspect is the perpetrator. In the case of the Golden State Killer, if matching DNA was recovered at many of the scenes that would be a good example of how the DNA evidence would have more weight.

Think also NATO forces e.g. in Afganistan. DNA sampling was main and the only method of identification for long time. I have not been able to find out what happened to that data.
Eventually yes, this is essentially future biometrics standard - lick/breathe on your computer to log in. No need for id, payment card, employee card or any card of sorts. But it is extremely opened for abuse.

I am curious when/where this will become the standard first. My bet is on China, of course, as this would very much fit in with their social credit score and totalitarian approach to society.

Derik does provide some push back to their ideas but ultimately they get the last word. The only counter to their position that is presented is the amorphic ideal of personal privacy. Sure, it's easy to weigh rapists and murderers being caught against your right to "privacy" but as we've seen in this video, law enforcement and genetic companies are willing to stretch what crimes worthy of using genetic information. They stretched it to include assault but what's to stop them from stretching it to include protesting. When tensions between police and civilians are at a boiling point, normal people have good reason to not want their genetic data in the hands of the police. These are points that could be made but are left out of the video. Despite Derik's gentle push back, this video does little to counter the narrative of law enforcement and private companies that your unwilling sacrifice of personal privacy is worth it if it helps them solve crimes. I get that the cases that could be solved by this technology are very tragic. I really do and I understand why someone would want systems like this to be available to law enforcement. But what I think hasn't been addressed enough in the video is the idea that this can very easily be abused to a catastrophic degree, if it ever falls into the wrong hands. It would ber very unwise to not at least consider that this would be the holy grail for any bad actor (and history shows that there have been enough of those).

The only time this was briefly addressed in the video was when it was mentioned on a side note that this could for example be abused by healthcare companys. This is of course a valid concern and honestly, that alone might be enough to disqalify the idea. But it doesn't even have to be in the private sector.


Just try to imagine the unfathomable amount of harm this could do if that kind of system were to fall in the hands of Nazis for instance.

I know many people are going to dislike this example, because people like to think that democracy is very robust and this scenario therefore completely out of the question. But I believe this to be wishful thinking. Mind you I am not one of these crazy people who equate modern democratic states to fascist dictatorships. All I am saying is that democracy is a fragile thing that needs to be protected very vigorously.
When Weimar Germany (read: a - not very well established, yet healty - democracy) was taken over by the Nazis, they did it by winning a fair democratic election. This fact combined with the subsequent totalitarian dictatorship (that took very little time to be fully established) and it's crimes show that we cannot assume that the government will always only be using such a system for very heinous crimes.

If we ever were in the situation that a fascistic (or any other form of extremistic) power would take over a government with access to such systems, we would face the devestating prospect of mass murder/genocide/eugenics on a scale the likes of which this world has never before seen.


Therefore when I weigh the possible benefits with the possible risks (and their respective likelyhoods as I perceive them), I cannot help myself but come to the conclusion that this is absolutely not worth it.

Anyways this was certainly a very interesting topic and a well made video. I just feel like it was a little one sided.

This comment section is overflowing with contradictions. If I've managed to decipher the line of reasoning here, I shouldn't trust the government, because it's corrupt, but the government is merely an organization of individual actors, so we should take power from the government and give it instead to individual actors. But isn't it ultimately individual actors who are corrupting the government? How does giving lawless, free reign of society to individuals offer any more protection? Libertarians are anarchists in disguise who are only capable of thinking in absolutes. Every collective decision made in a society is a balancing act between two competing ideals, and without collective decision-making, we don't have rights at all. Ultimately, this means that you need a government to moderate any right, including your right to privacy. (And if your problem is corporate data collection, then you really need to give your head a shake if you've taken an anti-governmental stance: these corporations are the natural product of an unregulated market dominated by individual actors, so if you think the government is the primary agent invading your privacy, you might want to think again and perhaps even ask your government to get more involved in the collective regulation of these individual actors.) As for those of you who are arguing that ancestral DNA identification could be used to suppress dissent, then you are forgetting that there are much more effective tools that are already in play to accomplish this goal.

The key argument presented in this video hinges on the idea that the greater good of the whole supersedes the need for individual privacy, which is the same sort of argument commonly used to justify the need to get jabbed. Although I can contend with the vast utility and benefits of the DNA database, handing off the “keys” to my privacy to the hands of another institution (including government bodies) that can easily usurp my privacy for the “greater good” and to the benefit of their needs is in my opinion, the very core of the problem.

Give an inch and instead a mile is taken – for the sake of the greater good – has always been historically repeated; and given this historical repeating significance, there is no reasonable basis to believe that our privacy will be protected no matter how balanced public policies, laws and regulations become to render individual privacy while still allowing access to such databases – because this is a logical contradiction. Benefit of the greater good supersedes the need for individual privacy is essentially euphemism to justify the intrusion of individual privacy (or individual rights), and this video clearly shows this sort of intrusion – that our genome sequences are already likely available inadvertently when a relative upload their information.

This isn’t to degrade the advancement of technology, science and this video; again, there’s no denying the vast utility and benefits of such database. It is rather to highlight the impossible nature of rendering public policies, laws and regulations that actually protect individual privacy while still allowing access to data bases by institutions and government bodies that has historically taken advantage of people’s rights and freedoms.

In some sense the main thrust of the issue presented here is not new, though. Like, on the one hand, if I commit a heinous crime and my brother has uploaded his DNA, they might use that to find me despite the fact that I didn't consent to my own information being uploaded and/or used for law enforcement. But in the same sense, I have a right to deny law enforcement entry to my home without a warrant, whereas let's say a spouse or roommate - if their name is also on the deed/lease - can consent to a search even if there is no warrant. Or that same brother could willingly show up to a precinct to offer information. Obviously the implementation here is different, but it's a similar idea in that while you have a right to control what you share about yourself, there are already avenues for others to share things about you without your consent.

The way the guests referred to privacy concerns deliberately downplays the real crux of the matter; that the "if you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear" argument only applies if the government and companies are acting in your best interest. It's all good and well to say that this is about preventing violent crime, but what about when it's about targeting anti-government activists? What about racial profiling for eugenic purposes? What about for preventing people from getting access to health insurance? These are what you should be worried about.

Derek: I'm extremely disappointed that this video doesn't discuss the potential for false convictions as a result of DNA evidence. This was an extremely one-sided video.

The chance of an individual person getting matched incorrectly in vanishingly small, which is what juries are told by the prosecution. But the chance of multiple matches to a given criminal's DNA is extremely *high*. Innocents can be implicated due to DNA evidence. This video is very dangerous in its incomplete picture.

Interesting topic, but we're missing a large part of the conversation -- once the data is out there, there is no more control over how it gets used. While the interviewed companies currently say "we only expose this data to LEOs for certain types of cases where the need is great enough" there is absolutely nothing stoping a merger, or takeover, or just a policy change, that says "we're going to give this data to election campaigns, insurance providers, employers, and anyone else with plan that makes users throw up in their mouth upon hearing it, as long as they pay us enough."

This is a very very similar problem with the discourse around government backdoors into encryption. They say they'll use it for good right now. Even if I trust them at their word right now, there is no guarantee of any kind that this will be true even one election cycle down the road. Or that bad actors won't find a way into the system.

What happens when insurance companies look at these (even the free and open sources mentioned in this video!) and start upping premiums for people with a predisposition to hereditary diseases? Or employers get into the system to run checks on applicants? Or political parties start doing unthinkable things?

Ultimately this is startlingly one-sided and misses so many arguments from the data protection and privacy standpoint, glossing over them with an "It's okay to feel this way, but it's helpful so you should still do it". I know you're more in the edutainment space than the deep-dive think piece space, but frankly, it is dangerous not to talk about. It is leaving people not only uninformed, but worse, incompletely informed.

I'm pretty disappointed because of how insidiously damaging to the discourse this can be. Yes, it is nuanced, and doesn't make for the best medium-form youtube content. But normalizing the acceptance of additional data gathering and allowing external access to these databases is hugely problematic, without taking equal effort to go into depth into the pitfalls therein.

My biggest issue with this video is that the golden state killer was a former police officer. It was completely glossed over; how can we trust the handling of this kind of data to the same system that allows a serial rapist and killer to work *for them*? This is not an isolated case; we’ve all seen the stats about how police officers tend to be more violent in the home than the general population.

Personally, I find a huge personal moral dilemma here. I think my DNA could be helpful to science, helpful to society, and helpful to my family — but at the same time, I massively distrust institutions to handle data this sensitive in nature. I think it wouldn’t take much for the genealogy companies to bend their rules under pressure or special cases.

I don’t fear the actual letter of the terms of service changing; rather, I fear that continued pressure by potentially law enforcement, health insurance, or other social systems will begin to erode at the original values set forth by these companies and give them some kind of irrefusible incentive to simply stop caring about the privacy of their customers.
