That CODIS probability of a match number you show near the beginning is wrong... And you pretty much explain why it is wrong with the rest of the video. Population structure
Back in the early days of DNA evidence, the FBI made some faulty assumptions about the distribution of those markers in the population. They aren't statistically independent and various markers are more common within different sub-populations. One of the bad assumptions was that those probabilities depended on "race"... which is true if you use "race" in the biological sense but not in the way folks use it everyday. There were other issues as well. Long story short, they did their statistics incorrectly.

My PhD advisor (Population Biology/Genetics) actually served as an expert witness against DNA evidence in some trials in those early days. Then the FBI changed the way they calculated those probabilities and were much less emphatic about the "1 in whatever" probability statements. After that he did some more expert witness testimony in support of DNA evidence... Actually did some work with the Innocence Project as well.
The Population Genetics class he taught (and I TAed a few times) used a lot of examples from this stuff ;)

PS: I'm actually revisiting this heredity and IBD (identity by descent) stuff right now because I'm trying to figure out better methods to estimate how far mosquitoes move/spread of the course of a few generations. That's pretty important to know when dealing with invasive species like Aedes aegypti (which can carry dengue) in CA or the controlled releases of GM mosquitoes like Oxitec are trialing in FL.

Gotta love the neoliberal fascism in this video. The single biggest logical fallacy this entire video makes is that laws = justice. The criminal justice system is horribly broken, and violence, generally, become less and less common. There are so many laws that aren't just but legal, and the criteria for what this information can be used for, as demonstrated in this video, is flexible and not rigid. So we have this incredibly powerful tool with far more potential for abuse than usefulness, being used to "solve" a problem that traditionally becomes less and less relevant to society (especially if society works on meeting basic needs of the citizens).
This sucks.

So the 710,000 figure is a little misleading, what the tech used in the video can only identify whether you have that specific SNP or not (e.g. do you have the blue eyes SNP) not whether it's an A/C/T/G at that position so really you will on average get a lot less than 710,000 datapoints from this assay. These services are not really worth much in my opinion, especially considering how much they charge for their VERY dubious interpretation of the SNP profiles they generate.

Security vs privacy, that's always the question. Allowing the police to access DNA databases would certainly solve more crimes, but I for one have no desire to allow our government to have access to the most sensitive and important information I possess. We've already given the government too much power, so no thank you.

But here's my 2 cents on the debate. I give up a blood sample every year as part of my annual medical checkup. I have absolutely no doubt that my DNA goes into some anonymized database used for medical research: that is a good thing IMHO. But that DNA record is just one step away from being part of a personally identifiable record, and I have no control over whether that step is taken. The conclusion that society should draw is not that freedom/privacy is being restricted, but that freedom to commit crimes with impunity is being restricted. Note also that wrongfully convicted people are being exonerated via DNA evidence. Anyone who is on the privacy side of the argument is also advocating for the enablement of crime with impunity and the incarceration of wrongfully convicted people: they need to reconcile themselves to that.

If a miscreant (that is someone who would be likely to "game" a system of such information) is allowed access - then the public could be harmed, as long as their Sub-Criminal Behavior is not disincentivized (currently only by Social Ostracism).

If / when Behavioral DNA (the Psychological equivalent of Physical DNA) ever becomes real (which it easily might in an approaching era of AI Analysis), then crime itself would be minimized, because those who would cause misuse of the Physical DNA evidence could also be traced, thereby causing a feedback loop of greater DNA being used for all kinds of discrete identity purposes. "White-Collar Crime" would also end.

A benefit of Behavioral DNA might be the conclusive origin of authorship in idea generation, the arts, and other complex behavioral outcomes.

This leaves the possibility that although Law Breakers convictions would be assured, Sub-Criminal miscreant behavior would also be punishable, by Digitally-Enforced ostracism in the "Court of Public Opinion".

Scary? Not for those who are victims of "anonymous" discrimination and oppression, because eventually such behavioral crimes (even as defined in future rights-based cases) would be forever knowable, and linked to the miscreants. So... In the name of law enforcement, yay DNA analysis and people allowing law enforcement to identify distant relatives. And yes, the argument made at 24:26 makes sense. Of course, identifying dangerous criminals outweighs the right to privacy of the offender. But just for a moment think of who has access to this data. Because we are not talking about proper checks and balances here. These are private companies maintaining databases to identify people who never gave these companies consent to collect that data. What prevents the CEO or other high-ranking members to help a friend find that guy that broke into his house, or stole 100 bucks, or parked in his driveway? What if someone with access to this data is a criminal himself, trying to identify potential victims? What if this data is stolen? What if it is leaked to the public or sold to the highest bidder?

The scale here has to be: Is it okay for everyone to be able to find anyone so that we can find criminals? Because at the end of the day no secret should be considered safe forever, no one fully trusted. Within the scale of a few hundred years, this data will be leaked and accessible if we continue to store and collect it. I don't think this should be the case. Collecting and storing this data shouldn't be legal. Not because I care about the right to privacy of criminals, but for those of everyone, everywhere. Because once that data is ever "out there", evil parties will use it. Oppressive governments can identify opposition or hunt minorities. Criminals can find the snitch or the perfect victim for insurance scams. And yes, even insurance companies could adjust their premiums thanks to your risk of getting sick.

Most people don't know this, but once upon a time (maybe still?), I think I read about it 15 years ago, several major printer brands would print out, on each printed page, a tiny, nearly-invisible grid of nearly-white dots in indistinguishable pale yellow ink. Single pixels. The positions of these dots identified via a simple code the specific serial number of the printer that printed them. Every page you printed had these on them, and you couldn't tell they were there with a naked eye, so, of course none of us ever noticed them. So, what's the problem with that? Well, suppose you're a murder, and you printed a page and left it at the scene. Law enforcement could eventually identify that your printed printed that page. Or your office printer, or whatever they seized with a warrant or perhaps whatever they could find in a warranty database. So far so good. But what about someone who printed pamphlets exposing for example government corruption? Someone trying to rally against a politician's opponent, or even just someone pushing for the power of police unions to be reduced? Now it's possible, with abuse, to to prevent corruption from being safe to expose. Genetic databases are the same. It's great to catch killers, rapists, and child abductors. But there is a massive potential to suppress dissent, and to make dissent too risky to consider.

But I worry that it presents a biased viewpoint by focusing so heavily on the ways this technology can be used for good and so little on the ways it can be abused. Most of the criticism you brought of this technology focused heavily on a very abstract "right to privacy" rather than the very concrete potential harms, which were only discussed for about 30 seconds. One thing that you did not talk about in the video was that innocent DNA can get to places in the crime scene where the law enforcement thinks came from the criminal. One case I've heard is that the criminal touched the same place than an innocent had touched moments before and the innocent's DNA travelled to the crime scene and inside a glove that the criminal was using to do the crime. So the law enforcement found that glove, it was accidentally dropped by the criminal, and found a match in the law enforcement database of an individual who had been arrested for possession of narcotics.

So not all DNA evidence is as reliable as people think. Thankfully current DNA experts in law enforcement know this, and in this particular case they were able to dismiss this innocent as a potential suspect quite quickly. In rape cases though the DNA is quite definitive as an evidence and mostly the DNA evidence from 2000 and before is only gotten from the bodily fluids of the criminal. Only afterwards we've been able to extract DNA from things like skin cells, hair follicles etc which are not as reliable as an indicator if someone actually was in the crime scene or not, and we need to be mindful of that fact.

I am not sure of the science and accuracy of the methods used to get to a suspect from ~1-2% match from a dna sample in the database already. Especially, since these methods seem to be using some inference based on a 'known probability' to create profiles. How do they account for mutations? What if one day someone lands in the miniscule chance of that and suddenly are convicted of serious crimes they never committed? From the video, I gather that in a court of law, this method as evidence is irrefutable unless you can prove that you are the exception and the jury would not even understand the complexities of the DNA analysis methods. I suppose with enough context in an investigation / interrogations, it could be a final nail in the coffin but I have a feeling that with new methods being touted as such perfect methods of finding the guilty, a mistake or assumptions made in the analysis process can potentially ruin innocent lives. Again, I am not an expert but I was expecting the video to flip the coin and explore the negatives and flaws of such methods and as others pointed out, I would have liked to see abuses of the privacy concerns also be addressed outside of criminal justice.

Cheek cells are easy to get off of coffee cups. There is one thing you have to be careful with here though, and that's how much certain people know, as via PCR, it is easy to create batches of select segments of DNA, which would be easily picked up if/when a sample is purposely left behind. Having done PCR and essentially something similar to what they do here (looking for fingerprints of viruses with nearer 100% accuracy from samples taken), generally, it is a reliable method for identification. But that same method of detection is a simple way to manufacture and then leave false evidence at a crime scene (if/when some know the process and have the equipment that makes a small smear on your cardboard coffee cup where you drank from (perhaps a few hundred cells) turn into 200, 400, 800, 1600, 3200 copies of some of those special segments).

The beauty though, in the whole of solving puzzles involving people, such as crimes, is that a majority of criminals in the 70s-2000s didn't know enough about DNA and RNA to concern themselves with that particular piece of evidence. Finger prints, perhaps, but hair samples, and even things as simple as the little bit of evidence left on a door handle is often more than enough to put together pieces of the puzzle. Now, just imagine when time travel comes into play (a valuing in the doubting of time travel now, like DNA in the past), and so no one gets away with a single crime.
Imagine something you'll see closer to this minute, with fishing through a given person's mind to gather information. Pair that with time travel, and you've their words, their actions, and their thoughts all incriminating them.

Take it a step further, use the best stealth tech and robotics you have, between time travel, mind monitoring, and stealth utilizing a trick involving space between and around atoms, and you've at least two little hovering robots watching you from birth to death - every single individual from Adam, to now and storing terabytes of data on the equivalent of SD cards from the future, while also transferring that data to what amounts to futuristic servers.

Essentially, there's no way around this though, which means anyone committing a crime is in essence already queued to be processed and imprisoned if they'd gotten away with a crime during their life time.

The last, and a simpler step than time travel itself, is the imbusing of immortality, for both punishment and reward. Essentially, that lie you thought you got away with when you were 10 will come to light (though most likely nothing will come of it). All in all, the search -- over a person's lifetime -- is for patterns, deviations, and pauses. Given a person's thoughts, nothing can be gotten away with.

Excellent video!
The trouble I have is “Law Enforcement” has already proven themselves to be untrustworthy with information databases.
For example, PDMP, or Prescription Drug Monitoring Program.
On the surface, PDMP is a lifesaving tool for emergency medical services. It allows EMT’s to quickly find and search your medical history for prescription drugs that may react with the lifesaving drugs they want to give to you.
Sounds like a good idea, right?
Well, most States consider their Law Enforcement as part of the “First Responder” group, and thereby allow them access to the PDMP.
Fact: if you are stopped by Law Enforcement, for whatever reason, and you provide them your information, they can search your PDMP history. Your consent is giving them your information.
Let’s say you are driving a car, and an Officer pulled you over. You provide your information, they look up your PDMP information and see that you were prescribed Vicodin. That is probable cause enough for the Officer to require you to perform a sobriety test.
It doesn’t matter if the prescription was from a dental procedure five years ago, and you haven’t taken Vicodin since. If it’s in your history, it’s probable cause.
The courts have repeatedly upheld this justification for violating privacy.
Near where I live, in Layton, Utah, an Officer used a woman’s PDMP history to force her to undergo a sobriety test. The Officer, under the guise of his personal safety, used the procedure to justify first handcuffing the woman and “patting” her down for weapons. There’s video on YouTube, you can clearly see the Officer groping and sexual assaulting the woman.
It’s a broad term “Law Enforcement.” It can mean anything from the rent-a-cop patrolling your HOA, to the foremost experts at the FBI.
When you say, “your DNA can be used to find and bring to Justice bad people.” Most Americans think, “okay, cool.”
But when you say, “Law Enforcement can track anyone anywhere using DNA.” Most Americans get very nervous, because most Americans don’t trust their local Law Enforcement.
Because, as Americans, we have repeatedly seen, time and time again, Law Enforcement Officer’s destroying the publics trust with zero ramifications.
I guess what I am trying to say is that America is a Police State. While it’s cool to suggest DNA can help to serve justice to criminals, it’s scary as hell to say DNA is one more way the Police State we already live in fear of, to keep us all under their thumb.

Solving cold cases by DNA-evidence does not really help with preventing new cases, does it? Not really a good argument. And something a lot of law enforcement guys forget or try to hide: They make errors sometimes. Even to the best of their effort, knowledge and belief. And such cases, where you do not have a lot of other evidence and have to rely on DNA, are more complicated and prone to errors. And not only criminals leave behind their DNA. There are a lot of ways someone's DNA might become subject of an investigation. Including deliberately placed. So do we really want to endanger innocent people to false accusations in favour of just knowing the truth in some cases that does not undo any damage? Violent cases are usually not the kind of crime where deterrence helps preventing it. Neither by the punishment nor ability to solve the crime. There are not many serial killers or rapist. Perhaps more in complicated cases, because you need to be somewhat skilled not to be caught your first time. So does it really prevent such crimes? Of course it will bring justice to old cases…but it might bring injustice in others.

24:15 You can use that same argument, and people have, to justify any number of overreaches into privacy, personal rights, et cetera. That is the same logic and reasoning, on a surface level, that Russia's Putin used to justify persecuting many of his political opponents in recent weeks. That's the same reason many people in China suffer the same. Same applies for many countries we consider authoritarian. It all sounds good on paper, "we're stopping criminals", "we're stopping terrorists", "we're stopping murderers".

To say "there has to be an equal balance" but then proceed to give absolutely no insight as to what that equal balance looks like... that's nothing but lipservice. And who's to decide what that equal balance will be? Who's there to stop it from being abused? A line was drawn at homicide any sexual assault. That line was crossed. We can all agree that strangling an old lady is absolutely heinous, but is that a good reason to push the system down the slippery slope? Slippery slope is only a fallacy if it's baseless, but they've already gone down that path of making exceptions, there is a clear basis for concern now.

And of course people who have no problem giving up their privacy will say things like "If you're not a criminal, you have nothing to be concerned about" just as they do for digital privacy as well, but it goes beyond that. Privacy doesn't exist only to protect or expose criminals. We take for granted that the state doesn't abuse and violate our privacy, and we laugh it off thinking "we're not China" or "we're not Russia", but some states have done very similar things in the past. Texas, or example, with their abortion ban... can you really expect the state of Texas to also respect privacy and not try and abuse this for more than the arbitrary line of "sexual assault and murder"?

Privacy is highly defended, because the opportunity for abuse is high, and once it's eroded there's no going back. And the line between what we think is a good cause and the kind of abuses we see in dystopian novels or in countries like Russia and China is very fine.

My initial reaction, without stewing over anything, is that we should all be DNA sampled but that there should be very clear and extremely conservative restrictions on how/when we can then be identified using that, and that most breaches of this privacy should possibly even be a felony. That way we're identifiable in the case of something severe like a sexual abuse or homicide and probably some more trivial things like "discovering your ethnic background," but people are heavily incentivized not to breach privacy.

It would then also make sense to have companies dedicated to creating security for that information so that it's very difficult to access except by approved methods, and anyone attempting to access it without cause can be caught more easily. Hopefully this would prevent the scenario of health insurance companies using your information to determine your rates as it would be a felony to do so and the chances of them 1) actually getting the information in the first place and 2) getting away with it ought to be pretty slim if multiple, competing, and entirely separate companies are providing security for a single, centralized database.

*I realize there are probably many problems/loopholes with this, just my first thoughts after watching.

For me it comes down to one thing. Trust. I am for there being searchable databases. That said, I also believe that there MUST be restrictions on what they can be used for and when they can be used. There have already been false convictions that resulted from improper use of DNA databases. Unfortunately the laws, in the US anyway, won't come into existence unless there is abuse of the databases. So for now, as far as I know, in many states it's all or nothing when it comes to searching these databases. If the choice is no searchability or unrestricted use, I say lock the police out.

There was one case where the person's DNA wasn't a close match but a relative was. The police used the vague DNA match to get a warrant search the persons property and found what they thought was a murder scene and went after the guy. He was actually trying to create a low budget horror film. He was prosecuted based on a fake murder scene for a movie and shaky DNA evidence. As a result his life was ruined. If I remember correctly he was fired, divorced, and as a result lost his house.

It's a tool so it very much depends on who wields it. Yes it could do a lot for justice in those limited scopes we discussed in the video. The point of DNA driven insurance policy is scary on its own, but it's also only the tip of the iceberg.

Some of the folks in the video really saw giving your DNA in the frame of murders only. My concern is about the ability for it to be used for injustice, prejudice, and oppression. Let's say a protest movement is 95% peaceful, let's say their cause is just, but let's say that just cause is also against the status quo and has entrenched opposition from those in power. If one of the 5% non peaceful protestors beat someone or sets some stores on fire, law enforcement might go to catch the perpetrators, but they could label all of the protestors are potential perpetrators and search all the DNA they could find for them too.

If we were a more totalitarian nationalist country (and for some time we were moving in that direction purposefully), as laws, directives, and orders themselves become totalitarian and likely unjust too. The press could be called the enemy, protestors could be called the enemy. Law enforcement upholds these official directives, morally just or unjust, which means this data and knowledge, could be abused so grievously for oppression.

Everything will be monitored live, from your heartbeat, blood pressure, I'll go out and say probably mind, they will know what you think, and if you misbehave you'll be sanctioned, or neutralized. Sounds crazy? I know, just look with everything that's happening in the world now, it's looking like we are headed there. Every word you search online, tracked. Every word said recorded. Our freedoms are taken away step by step, it's a gradual process. I sound dramatic, I know. But this is no laughing matter, rest assured. We are not just gradually enslaved, we are turning into the same machines we deem soulless. We as people have became like shadows, while our digital footprints became our active personas. We are gradually losing our will, our souls. Just think about this: If you lose your phone, you've lost more information of yourself than if you personally went missing. How crazy is that notion? Without the right precautions, all your data, probably even accounts, including your money, or similar assets all compromised. Your literal livelihood can be compromised by a single "device".
This insanity should be stopped before it's began. It has been going on for years, well decades now, far too long. Of course you can say this is a useful tool. Like all tools are. At 19:19 one of the guests is talking about genetic information as it relates to Health Insurance, but there is already a federal law, the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act of 2008, which deals with this topic in the USA. Essentially it prohibits discrimination based on genetic information for health insurance and employment purposes. Admittedly, that is fairly limited, and there are more concerns with discrimination for loans or housing, but many states have more comprehensive laws. So the laws are not as far behind as presented, though it also depends on what specific country you're talking about.

I know this video is about people's commercial DNA tests being used to identify somewhat distantly related criminals, but it misses that the future of genetics will likely be that the vast majority of people will have their DNA in some kind of database for healthcare reasons. This is typically called genomic medicine, it is a powerful tool in diagnostics and treatment decisions, and it will likely become mainstream in the coming decades. This is an important step forward in healthcare because it will be replacing less accurate race and ethnicity based medical information when deciding which treatments would be less effective, more harmful, or more beneficial.

I think many people are misunderstanding the role these databases play in solving crimes. Many seem to imagine that the evidence presentation in court would go something like this: "we found this guy because the DNA databases singled him out, therefore he is guilty." In reality, that would be hearsay and not allowable as evidence. The prerequisite for using the databases is that there already exists a DNA sample LEFT AT THE CRIME SCENE by the criminal, against which a sample can be obtained by law enforcement, from the individual singled out by the data base, and shown to be a match.

In essence, the DNA database is really no more investigatively innovative than publishing an article saying "hey community, does anyone know a guy who's pretty tall, drives an early 90's Bronco, has a scar on his left cheek, and is missing three fingers on his right hand?" It merely serves as a means of narrowing a search down to one or several suspects. From there, guilt still must be established and provable in court, using the same standards of evidence that are normally required. The fact that police arrived at the suspect through a DNA database, while new and exciting, really does not challenge privacy issues as they relate to the law and enforcement of it. The DNA obtained from the suspect still has to be matched to the DNA recovered from the crime scene, and that evidence still must be presented to a jury for conviction.

If no DNA is left at the scene of the crime, there can be no DNA database search. Therefore, privacy concerns shouldn't exist if you haven't left your DNA all over a crime scene, because no manner of data science is going to identify you from a DNA database without a sample of your DNA to start the search.

You missed a very important point: while matching DNA (which doesn't mean identical DNA since we only look at a subset) is indeed unlikely between two random people, it becomes more and more likely the more people you test and these techniques effectively test hundreds of millions of people.

DNA is not unique, much less the small subset tested by the police.

Juries are not being told how far more likely it is that a suspect found via this path is to have a randomly matching DNA than a suspect that was found because he was caught running a block away from a crime.

Instead juries are being led to believe that DNA evidence equals to near absolute certainty, leading to the conviction of innocent people.

Experts in trials often mislead juries on the likelihood of a DNA match.

If even an half hour in-depth video on the topic cannot mention this problem, we are paving the road to more injustice in the justice system.

I've read a bunch of comments concerned with the message of this video, with many criticizing the supposed balance between the public good and personal privacy. In addition, many seem concerned that the video is heavily bias, even if made exceptionally well.

Honestly, I didn't know what to think at first, however, more and more, I'm starting to agree with the criticisms.

First of all, personal privacy and the public good are not opposites, nor does having one mean we can't have the other. A system which only works for the supposed "public good" only works when the public good is actually beneficial to the public.

Once a politician creates a paradigm shift on what "public good" means or someone finds a way to take advantage of the system in place, everyone and everything we've sacrificed for the public good goes right out the window. The fact of the matter is that they aren't mutually exclusive ideas.

Consider this: A system that can identify anyone, even those who don't submit DNA, can also be used for nefarious purposes. DNA evidence can be planted, and when the system we use to solve these cases are primarily based on DNA it means there's no counter-balance.

Even if we were to assume that these organizations are 100% focused on doing the morally right thing, (an assumption I'm unwilling to make), can we really say the same when the next generation, organization, etc takes over? There's no guarantee.

Second of all, the bias in this video really is a problem. How can one craft an objective viewpoint whilst locked into an echo chamber?

I find it troubling that the video talks about them collecting our DNA so nonchalantly, as if they were talking about windmills or something. Would the same attitude be taken towards nuclear bombs?

The fact that nobody truly considers the issues with this methodology, (only going as far as to lightly address the fact that there ARE issues), simply demonstrates a level of irresponsibility that's, frankly, frightening. Again, wouldn't you be worried if someone had the same attitude towards a nuclear bomb?

The part at the end, with DuckDuckGo, showed a bit of irony, one that may or may not be intentional.

This is the second video on this channel in the past couple months (the first being the self-driving cars one) that has felt disturbingly sponsored to me (not necessarily monetarily, though the last one was, but rather it's trying to tell an overly simple story about a very complex issue in a way intended to sway public opinion in a particular direction). There a tremendous number of problems with making DNA data available that are never even addressed here in order to give the impression that it's just a civic responsibility vs. selfish privacy issue. They briefly touch on what might happen if insurance companies got their hands on that information, but that's only the tip of the iceberg.

The fundamental problem is that there is no limitation on how this information will be used. No matter what they say right now, eventually it's use will expand and others who shouldn't be able to access the database will. No database is perfectly secure.

As a human biologist, I think that getting so much DNA data has many ethical consequences for basic research. Today, we can decipher the DNA sequence of a human for 80 dollars (the costs were over 100 million dollars 15 years ago). This is very beneficial as we can conduct huge studies and identify how variations of genes cause or protect against certain diseases. A variation of CCR5 for example makes you completely resistant against HIV and we can try to engineer cells to cure HIV patients (I'm preparing a video on that). But then there are privacy concerns and the question remains how much we should look into the DNA of people.

I am opposed to the idea of a DNA database, because there are Diseases out there (like Huntington) that are genetic and that are incredibly severe. In that case once an insurance gets their hands on that information (and they will, absolutely) it's not going to be the case of "skyrocketing rates" for these people. They will not get insurance anymore. They will likely get rejected from a lot of jobs (because no company wants to train and pay for an employee that is at risk of dying). Privacy related to medical problems is not just a matter of rising health insurance or because people don't want the world to see their problems. In our society it can very easily lead to a situation of ruining someones life. I get that it can help law enforcement, but when you see how misused and abused the tools are that law enforcement already has, I think the negatives strongly outweigh the positives here. It only takes one weak link or one lapse of judgment and suddenly you have a leak of the health information of millions of people.

There's a lot to unpack in this video. First and foremost is that DNA evidence has been used to convict and even execute people that were later proven innocent. There's even a race bias at play, both from the law enforcement aspect and the sampling groups. I'm a huge fan of your channel, and I feel weird that this side of it was left out entirely.

The other big thing to mention has been said by many others in the comments, and that's that the conversation around individual rights and society is framed with a huge bias. Does someone's privacy outweigh catching a criminal? Is it ok to search through the lives of dozens, or even hundreds of innocent people without consent in order to catch a single criminal? Wouldn't zero privacy technically be the ultimate public safety tool, so why have privacy at all? I'm not answering these questions for anyone, but I think the implications are scary.

A scientist went to Panama to study the DNA of the indigenous peoples there.  This scientist then went and patented their DNA with the knowledge or consent of person involved.  It is hard to believe that the indigenous individual who gave up their DNA even realized the implications of getting their cheek swabbed. Some scientist might make a medicine from your DNA and you might not even know about it let alone get a share of the income.  Or the big corporations could just wait until you are dead and then suddenly discover this new medicine which will make them a bundle and they have nobody around to contest them.  Police access is not the only DNA privacy concern.

It's hard to be against, in principle, the consensual use of DNA to find perpetrators of the most serious crimes. The issue I have is that institutions have a habit of falling short of their professed standards. There is always the danger moral backsliding and the progressive normalisation of ever lower ethical standards, especially when there are institutional pressures and incentives for a race to the bottom. It would be wrong to say that this is inevitably what must happen, but there is obviously a significant risk of it happening. And trusting the government to respect the privacy of their citizens was always naive, but, post-Snowden, it is downright absurd. If there is a database anywhere - private or public hands - I simply don't trust the surveillance state to keep its invasive tentacles away from it. The sensible thing, to my mind, is to keep a comfortably safe distance from the moral cliff-edge, rather than skirting up to it as closely as possible. It is difficult not to feel that we are courting disaster.
